headline: Easy White Chicken Chili
description: This white chicken chili with beans, green chiles, and oregano is easy and delicious! Top with shredded cheese for a comforting meal on a cold day.

video.description: Try this lighter version of chili with chicken and cannellini beans.
video.name: Easy White Chicken Chili

name: Easy White Chicken Chili
recipeIngredient: 3 (15 ounce) cans cannellini (white kidney) beans, rinsed and drained
2 pinches cayenne pepper, or to taste
0.25 cup chopped fresh cilantro, or to taste
0.5 cup shredded Monterey Jack cheese, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Heat olive oil in a Dutch oven over medium heat. Cook chicken, onion, and garlic in hot oil until chicken is browned on both sides, about 5 minutes.
Transfer chicken to a cutting board; cut into 1-inch pieces.

Return chicken pieces to the Dutch oven. Add chicken broth, cannellini beans, green chiles, oregano, cumin, and cayenne pepper. Bring the mixture to a simmer and cook until the chicken is cooked through, 30 to 40 minutes.
Divide cilantro among 4 bowls. Ladle chili over cilantro and top with cheese. Season with salt to serve.

review.reviewBody: I thought is was good. There can be so many substitutions as far as spices. I will make it again. The recipe was very helpful. Thank you

We love this white chicken chili. It is so easy and adaptable. I added 1/4 of a tsp of ground coriander because I always use coriander when I am using cumin. I like the combination. When I don’t have cilantro I substitute then green tops of green onions. A pop of color with a mild flavor.

I loved this recipe but I'm all about shortcuts. Using half of a deboned rotisserie chicken. Boiling the skin and bones for the broth. (Adding a little celery, onion powder and bay leaf). Strain off the stock and use what you need. I used 4 cups. Dumping it all into the crockpot (on low) and walk away. To make it thicker I smashed 1 can of beans and shredded my cut up chicken, To kick it up a notch I used 1 can of HOT green chilis. And finally adding a half a brick of cream cheese to make it sinfully good..
Flavor is amazing. I went easy on the spices. On the list to make again
Love it! I add cream cheese and half and half to make it creamy.

Easy recipe. Good as is. I did not have cilantro, but used a few drops of Tabasco sauce in my bowl for a touch more of spice. My sister just made it with ground turkey and brought me some since I just got out of the hospital. It was good too but not as tasty as the chicken. Best made the day before serving.
Delicious. But I also like to add corn and one brick of cream cheese instead of the Monterey Jack.
I always use rotisserie chicken and substitute cilantro with fresh chopped parsley. Also chicken stock to replace chicken broth. Much richer flavors. Great easy and delicious.

This recipe is great, mine turned out a little darker due to the browning the chicken and the seasonings and drippings from the pan deepened the flavor and color of chili overall. I also made some additions just for flavor. I added more seasoning to taste, cumin, garlic powder, salt, white pepper and Knoll Tomato Chicken Bouillon powder. I also mashed one of the cans of beans for a thickener as well as a little flour for just a slightly thicker chili. Serve with a dollop of sour cream and some tri-colored tortilla strips you find in the produce section for salad toppers. Very delicious!
This was very simple to make and tasty. I wouldn't change a thing.

This is an excellent recipe for someone with high blood sugar. The beans provide good carbs while minimizing the simple carbs. I have made this, and it is pretty good. In fact, I am making this again tonight.

Super tasty but I did change it up a bit due to what I had on hand. Plus I didn't think it was spicy enough for our tastes. So, I added 3 tsp of chili powder, a few shakes of red pepper flakes, and a couple extra pinches of cayenne pepper. I used rotisserie chicken instead of breast. I also only had one can of canella beans so I subbed some pinto and added 1/2 cup instant rice. Also added 1 cup heavy cream (more calories but richer tasting).
I loved this. I made the several changes others did, I added corn, peppers a can of tomatoes. It was better the next day. My husband and son in law loved it!!

This is really chicken and bean soup. I made this twice now trying to thicken it up to a more chili-like consistency. I cooked and pureed an additional can of beans, added corn starch, reduced liquid to 3 cups. Now its chili, not soup! Love the original recipe spices.
I would make it a bit less soupy next time. And I only added 4 cups of broth. But very flavorful

I did make a couple slight changes:
Used only 4 cups chicken broth, omitted the peppers and used a deboned chicken.
I thought it turned out well and will make again

I made this and it was good. I did make a few changes. I only used 2 cups of chicken broth and I added a cup of heavy cream. I also used 3 cans of great northern beans. I didn’t have any garlic cloves so I used garlic powder. I served it with tortilla strips. Will make again.
Used shredded chicken and used a couple different types of beans. Was tasty

This was an excellent recipe with room to add extras. I did blend half of the beans as I red the reviews and prefer a but of a thicker chili.. And I added tomatoes and frozen corn. Easy, filling and healthy !
Really good. Used only 4 cups chicken broth and puréed the 3 can of beans to thicken. Served it over white rice and a side of cornbread. Deeeeelish!
Will make this again. It was delicious!!
One of my favorite recipes. Double the flavor the next day.
Delicious! We made homemade corn tortilla chips to go with it. Yum!
I used turkey for this recipe ground and cubes. It turned out great.
This recipe is quick and very tasty. I like that I usually have all the ingredients on hand (with the exception of cilantro). It tasted even better the next day!
It's simple and tasty. Easy to make for a group and is a crowd pleaser. You can add a dollop of sour cream to it at the table if you like it creamy.
We all love this and I particularly love the tangyness of the green chilies. This is so easy it will be one of our favorites.
That's a lot of chilis and cayenne! If you're like my little siblings, that's too much. No need for all of that. The ones of us who wanted it spicier just added cayenne pepper into their own soup
I used bush’s white chilie beans (great northern beans)
My husband love it will make it again

Fantastic flavor! As other reviewers recommended, I blended one can of beans with a bit of chicken broth to add more thickness. Served with freshly-sliced jalapenos and avocado, this was a huge hit in our house!
family favorite I don't use the green chilies. I use roasted Reds. Also, I do three cans of beans in it. And two cans pureed in the food processor. To give it that thicker consistency.
I use dried onions and herbs during winter for ease and time. I also shred meat from a rotisserie chicken to save time.

Cooked chicken tenderloins in olive oil until done. Removed from pot. To pot added onion, garlic and one chopped green pepper. Cooked until tender. Added 2 cans of beans, another can drained, one can of chili peppers and 4 cups of chicken broth (don’t think you need anymore plus I read reviews beforehand saying it was too soupy) After adding spices, added chicken back in and cooked for 1 hour. Served with avocado, cheese and chopped cilantro. Yummy. I would probably up the spices next time. I like a little more kick but hubby added tobacco and he was happy. Easy, healthy meal.
Adjusted recipe for 2 and used Knorr Chicken flavored bouillon in the jar. Didn’t have any cilantro (raining to hard to go out) and it was delicious and not very spicy. Definitely a keeper.

The broth made this a winner. I usually add noodles to my chili anyway, so I added it to this one as well. Very filling with just one helping. I made this for a get together. I added about 7 cubes of chicken buillion with the equivalent water; plus peeled, diced tomatoes. I also added one other chicken breast and shredded the chicken. I will make this again. Love the green chilies.
It was very easy to make. I made a few changes to the original recipe to make it my own. My family and friends loved it!
I loved it. I added diced tomatoes with green chilis.
Used grilled chicken and thickened it a bit with a roue. Served with avocado. Big hit with my family.
Delicious! I used leftover shredded chicken I had cooked in the crock pot.

I was looking for a different recipe when I came across this one that had similar ingredients to what I am used to. This recipe is perfect as is but if you like it spicy you'd definitely want to increase the cayenne pepper quite a bit. Easy peasy and very yummy!

I've been making this for years, always doubling the recipe because it freezes well. However, I'm always requested to bring it to tailgate parties and this is where the embellishments come in! Double the recipe, quadruple the amount of cumin, add 4 tbsp. Hot chili powder, a cup or two of frozen corn kernels. (I skip cayenne, but do add 2-3 shots of sciracha). Of course, the chili is no longer white, but the flavor is wonderful. This will fill the slow cooker. Other tailgaters wander by, enticed by the aroma. There is never any left.

I added the cilantro in while cooking. Also after I sauteed the onion, I transferred everything into a crockpot and left on high for 5 hours. Everyone enjoyed it! It's great with sour cream mixed in when served. 
Thank You!
My family really enjoyed this meal on a crisp, chilly day. I did add more of all spices and I mixed the cheese into chili. Will be making this again.

As presented, the recipe was rather bland with the consistency of plain broth. Taking suggestions from a previous review, I blended 1 can of beans with some of the broth and poured it back in to thicken it. I also blended in 8 oz cream cheese which made a fantastically creamy sauce. Instead of the cilantro we opted for sliced fresh jalapeño. With those changes I’ll make this again.
The dish taste great, but had to much liquid in it for me. Chili should be thick. May be more beans would help.

I love the combination of flavors and the simplicity of this chili which is more like a soup, but I love a great soup!
The only change I made was substituting one of the cans of cannellini beans with Great Northern beans. 
I also experimented by adding some instant potato flakes at the end in an effort to thicken it a bit. I will make it again and I have already shared the recipe with a friend who loved it.
Se easy and so good on a cold snowy day. Put a touch of sriracha sauce after it was served
Love this recipe! The only thing I changed was I used ground chicken instead of shredded. It was a big time saver and tasted excellent. This will definitely be in our regular dinner rotation.

I made this and it was great. I did make some minor adjustments. 5 cups of the broth was perfect . I also cut the chicken into chunks ahead of time, then mixed about half of the seasoning with about 2 tsp of oil to coat the cut up chicken and refrigerated for about an hour. This simplified things as once the chicken was browned I just added the rest of the ingredients. I also added about a cup of diced red bell peppers. One additional can of beans mashed up to thicken the chili as suggested by another reviewer worked well. This is a really good recipe and is very easy to make.

I didn't want to make a big batch so I modified and added some ingredients. I used rotisserie chicken, 2 cans of white beans, 1 can of green chilies, 1/2 onion, 1 clove garlic, 1 container of chicken broth, 1 tsp. cumin. I added 1/2 cup heavy cream and a can of corn, a squirt of cilatro paste and about 1 cup of cheddar cheese into the soup. It turned out great. I seasoned with herbamare.
ADDED CORN ROTEL AVACADO ON TOP
I made it exactly as the recipe suggested and it turned out very tasty!
Tastes great but too thin--more like soup. I prefer a thicker chili.

We really love this recipe. It's so easy with leftover chicken, my teen (14yo) can handle making this. I'm not entirely sure what he did the last time, he thinks he added some leftover heavy cream or half and half, and it was crazy good also. But this recipe "as is", is a staple in our house.
Please, if you change a recipe, DON'T rate it!!!
Was good
So I changed the serving size to serve 8 and ended up basically making this into a soup which honestly, I loved!!! Great for a chilly Western NY winter day.
Loved the recipe. I added fresh kale and carrots. This chili is easy and quick. Will make it often.

This makes for a yummy meal on a rainy day. My husband and I gave it a strong B+. It has lots of flavor and I loved the added 2 pinches of cayenne pepper. I liked it lighter on the cilantro but a small amount of cilantro was nice for a fresh taste. I plan to make again.
I’ve made this dish many times. It’s always a winner!
It was more like soup like some have said but still very good. I downsized the recipe to fit our needs and added Himalayan salt. I had mine with Jasmine rice and my son ate his plain.
Didn’t have any green chilies and it was snowing so I added some Penzey’s pepper spices. It was really tasty.
Initially it was too bland for our taste, so I added a small diced serrano pepper and a tablespoon of chipotle chopped pepper. Still kept the white look, but added some nice tang !
1/4 t. White pepper, 6 more cups chic broth, 3 beef bullion cubes, 1 t. Salt, 1 t. Cracked Black pepper corn
Didn't make any changes except chicken stock instead of broth. 4 1/2 cups. wonderful flavor
Quick and simple

we make this a lot. I like to sub in ground turkey or chicken for the meat. add a can of beans (pinto or cannelini) and pulverize them before you put them in to help thicken it up. add a package of frozen corn.
wonderful to use up left-over chicken. The family raved about it.

So good and so simple! I cooked my chicken in the oven (with just a spray of olive oil), and then used the juices to cook the onions and garlic on top of the stove. I also added a can of whole kernel/nibblet corn. I was light on spices. Soo delicious!

The flavor is really good but it’s more of a soup then a chili. Even though I cut the liquid by one cup, drain the beans, and puréed one can of the beans. It’s still too liquidy to be called a chili. But the flavor really is good.
I used leftover chicken and only 2 cans of beans. Upped the cayenne to 1/2 tsp. but might be too spicy for those who don’t like spice. This recipe is GREAT!
This was delicious!! Next time I will add a can of corn drained. I also put a dollop of sour cream on top. Will add to my menu!
Tasty and easy. Naturally I added more garlic than it called for but I always do. We served it with cornbread. Very filling Halloween meal!
Added black beans and corn.

I used dried cannelli beans that had been soaked overnight. I pureed about 1 cup of them with the broth to thicken the soup as another reader suggested. I also added a few shakes of cajun seasoned salt . It was a hit with the family.
Wonderful recipe. I skip the cilantro and shred the chicken instead of slice it. I also add a bit of arrowroot powder slurry to thicken it a bit and add a TSP of minced garlic.

After I read all the reviews, I changed it up by adding corn and a can of diced tomatoes, and also pureed one can of the beans to make it thicker. I added more cumin and oregano too. This was more like a "soup" than a chili but it tasted great for my work gathering, and my husband enjoyed the leftovers. On the side I served chopped avocado, chopped green onions, and tortilla strips. It was a hit.
love this receipe i add a half block of cream cheese as well to kake it more creamer

I made this in the pressure cooker and it was ready within 15 minutes. Used boneless skinless chicken tenderloins, added bell peppers, added some cajun seasoning and served it with quinoa and garnished with chopped green onions. The family loved it - both of my toddlers gobbled it up. Next time, I'd thicken it a little - was soupy.
Added masa flour to thicken it. The flavor is wonderful!
I fixed the soup for teachers meeting, they all loved it and raved about it!!!
Have made several times. I will add homey sometimes . I also blend 1 or 2 extra cans of beans to thicken it. Freezes .well.
This was amazing. I love this chili better than a red chili.
I crushed one can of cannellini beans and I added fresh spinach on top.
Added yellow bell pepper.
We are newly weds, and I actually made this recipe in the crock pot during our first week of marriage. Such a time saver and a big hit with the hubby! ;)
It WAS easy and super yummy! Thanks for sharing your recipe!
This is a delightful, healthy and very tasty updated version of an old standard. I added cubed red pepper and some additional seasoning as well as thickening with flour. Quite delicious!

This is a good recipe. I like the creamier broth in this recipe because of the cream of chicken soup. I did not have enough chicken, so I adjusted the seasonings accordingly (1 tsp of cumin and oregano). I added a chopped and seeded poblano pepper to the recipe. I did not add the olive oil, since the chicken I was using was leftover and already cooked.

I made this for hubby.. he's on a low or no carb diet and this is a good Chicken Chili just for him! I only put in 1 can of the green chiles because I'm not a fan of them and I wanted to eat it too. 

It was very tasty... full of flavor and I'll make it again!

Based on other reviews, I used 1 less cup of chicken broth and added an extra clove of garlic and 1 heaping teaspoon of cayenne pepper to boost the flavor. I also used fire roasted green chili’s. I served it with a dollop of sour cream and a four cheese blend including pepper jack. I would definitely make again.

When I make this recipe, I do something a little bit different. I add 8 ounces of cream cheese. It makes it creamy and eliminates the tanginess, for my kids. It makes it more palatable for my three daughters.
Love this recipe and make it often! I replace the cheese with a can of coconut milk to give it the creaminess since I do not eat dairy. Excellent and easy! Hubby loves it to, which is a bonus.

I used ground chicken and cut back on most of the ingredients. I let it simmer a couple hours thinking it would thicken a bit. 
 Next time I will try to puree some of the beans to thicken it up. Super easy and good flavor.
This was a super substitution for tomato and beef chili!
I made this in a pressure cooker and it came out absolutely fabulous! I used rotisserie chicken (organic).

A good one! Even my young daughters liked it. A bit on the "cumin" side for me but still good staple to add to the list of ones kids like and will eat. Served with a sprinkle of parm cheese and some honey cornbread muffins! Yum!
Wasn’t a huge fan. Unlike other white chicken chili’s - this recipe was very watery and didn’t have as much flavor as I’d like from a “chili”

made this twice, people went back for seconds at a potluck, instead of all the spices I just add 2 packets of taco seasoning, 2 tsp of red chili powder, 1 tsp of oregano. 1 also decreased the water/stock to just 1 box of stock and reduced the whole thing down till it was thick enough to have over tostitos topped with sour cream, green onions (or chives) and mexican blend cheese. The key to making chili is never throw out the juices that come with the beans, just dump them into the chilli! Also great to eat alone with a spoon, without adding any other carbs/fats.
